author: Grey Papke
title: Ex-Ohio State QB has major criticism of Miami program
text:
Ex-Ohio State QB has major criticism of Miami program
The Miami Hurricanes finished off another underwhelming season Thursday with a Pinstripe Bowl loss to Rutgers, prompting one former national champion quarterback to deliver a damning verdict about their program.
Cardale Jones, who guided the Ohio State Buckeyes to a title in 2014, said on X Thursday he felt “bad” for any recruits that had committed to Miami for NIL money. To Jones, the Hurricanes have an unstable program with a terrible home atmosphere, and that “chasing the money isn’t always the answer.”
Man, I feel bad for the recruits going to Miami U for NIL…….. bad staff, no stability within program and one of the worst college home game atmospheres.
Chasing the money isn’t always the answer. But good luck
— Cardale Jones (@CJ1two)
[December 28, 2023]
The Hurricanes are a long way removed from the glory days of the early 2000s. Though they have a robust NIL program that
has helped recruit some top talent, the program still appears to be treading water. Despite the splashy hire of Mario Cristobal as coach prior to the 2022 season, the Hurricanes finished just 7-6 this season, dropping Cristobal to 12-13 since his return to the school. He has also faced criticism for some of his game management.
Miami will certainly be a factor in recruiting battles, and they are bringing in another highly-rated class for 2024. If things don’t turn around on the field, however, Jones’ commentary will probably be echoed by many others.

author: Not the Bee
title: VIDEO: Huge wave floods the streets of Ventura, California as storms push tides to abnormally high levels
text:
They told us there would be some bomb waves on the west coast this week due to offshore storms, but I didn't realize they were talking this big.
Yes sir, that's like a mini tsunami right there, so those must be some powerful storms out on the Pacific.
Another angle:
Man, that is both scary and awesome at the same time. Citizens of California's beach towns have mostly ignored calls to evacuate, and believe it or not, despite warnings from the National Weather Service, there are surfers out there catching some of these waves. The rip current is incredibly powerful right now, and anyone risking their lives out there for a gnarly wave is either insane or has a death wish (or both).
At least 8 people were hospitalized when gigantic waves wreaked havoc across coastal California towns on Thursday, as powerful storms hovered over the Pacific Ocean.
Daring residents ignored evacuation orders and flocked to the beaches to watch the epic show of the waves crashing, but some were too close as the monstrous waves broke over the seawalls.
A rogue wave swept approximately 20 beachgoers at Pierpont Beach around 11 a.m. in Ventura.
A few more shots of the California coast:
Debris including driftwood and logs were reported to have washed up on shore in the [Ventura] area.
"They're washing logs up here. A lot of debris, a lot of driftwood. So we've been asking people to avoid the direct coastal area," Keehn added.
The Ventura Fire Department said it was working overnight to create artificial beach berms to protect the nearby residential neighborhoods …
The entire west coast from Washington down to the US-Mexico border is also under High wave warnings and advisories until 3 a.m. local time Friday with coastal flooding warnings in effect until the afternoon.
Pretty scary stuff out there in California, but it looks like it'll be over shortly.

author: Field Level Media
title: Cubs open series with Royals desperate to find offense
text:
The fading Chicago Cubs open a three-game series against the host Kansas City Royals, hoping their first road trip after the All-Star break goes better than the six home games that preceded it.
Needing wins badly to climb into wild-card contention to start the second half, the Cubs saw their offense fall flat. They scored no more than three runs in any of the six games and lost two of three games each to the Arizona Diamondbacks and division rival Milwaukee Brewers.
"We pitched well," Cubs manager Craig Counsell said. "We didn't score enough runs."
Chicago stranded 22 baserunners while batting 3-for-19 with runners in scoring position against Milwaukee.
"We just didn't do enough offensively," Counsell said after Wednesday's 3-2 loss. "It was very quiet. There wasn't any traffic. There wasn't any at-bats to put pressure on them. It was a light offensive day."
Following a season-best five-game winning streak when the Cubs scored at least four runs per game, the Cubs were within three games of .500 and 2 1/2 games of the third wild-card spot. But they have dropped six of nine games since then and lost all three series while scoring 24 total runs. Eight of those runs came in one of the victories.
The struggling offense could soon get a boost with the return of Cody Bellinger.
On the injured list with a non-displaced fracture of his left middle finger after being hit by a pitch July 10, Bellinger took part in a pregame workout Wednesday.
"He had a really good workout," Counsell said after Bellinger's on-field batting practice session Tuesday.
Bellinger is not expected to require a rehab assignment, and Counsell indicated he may initially use Bellinger in the designated hitter role upon his return.
Right-handers Kyle Hendricks (2-8, 6.69 ERA) and Brady Singer (6-6, 3.00) take the mound in Friday's opener.
Hendricks is 2-0 with a 1.40 ERA in three career starts covering 19 1/3 innings against the Royals. Most recently, he gave Kansas City just one unearned run over six innings on Aug. 20, 2023, in a 4-3 win.
Adam Frazier has two homers and two doubles while hitting .419 (13-for-31) with three RBIs and three walks against Hendricks.
In six starts since returning to the rotation June 19, Hendricks is 2-4 with a 4.45 ERA.
In two starts against the Cubs, Singer is 0-2 with an 8.31 ERA. Last Aug. 19, he took the loss after allowing six runs -- four earned -- on nine hits and two walks in 3 2/3 innings. He gave up two home runs.
Singer has allowed more than one run just once in his last six starts, and most recently, he tossed seven shutout innings against the White Sox on Saturday.
Jac Caglianone, the Royals' 2024 first-round draft pick (sixth overall), met with media in Kansas City on Wednesday afternoon shortly after signing with the club. He agreed to a $7.5 million signing bonus.
Caglianone was the 2024 John Olerud Award winner as the best collegiate two-way player. Caglianone hit .419 in 66 games with 35 homers -- second-most among Division I hitters -- and the left-hander was also 5-2 with a 4.76 ERA in 16 starts, helping the Florida Gators reach the College World Series semifinals.
Royals general manager J.J. Picollo addressed questions about whether Caglianone would focus on hitting or pitching.
"He had a full season pitching this year," Picollo said. "The priority right now is to just let him go out and hit. That's the commonsense thing to do."
Pitching may still be in Caglianone's future, however.
"I can see that happening," Royals area scout Nick Presto said. "He can do whatever he wants."
--Field Level Media

author: Deseret Digital Media
title: US judge upholds Trump's $83.3M defamation loss, rejects new trial | KSL.com
text: Estimated read time: 2-3 minutes NEW YORK — A federal judge on Thursday rejected Donald Trump's bid to throw out an $83.3 million defamation verdict in favor of the writer E. Jean Carroll, who said the former U.S. president defamed her after she accused him of raping her decades ago. U.S. District Judge Lewis Kaplan in Manhattan [denied Trump's requests](https://www.ksl.com/article/50944411/trump-appeals-e-jean-carrolls-833m-defamation-verdict) for a new trial, or to have the former Elle magazine advice columnist's case thrown out altogether. He also dismissed arguments that the jury's award to Carroll following Trump's "malicious and unceasing attacks" was too high, and that errors at the civil trial tainted the verdict. Trump is appealing the verdict, and plans to appeal Thursday's decision. "We categorically disagree with Judge Kaplan's decision," his lawyer Alina Habba said in a statement. "It ignores long-standing constitutional principles and is a prime example of the lawfare raging across this country." Roberta Kaplan, a lawyer for Carroll, said she was not surprised by the decision, and said the $83.3 million award was "entirely reasonable." She is not related to the judge. Trump is the Republican presidential candidate in the 2024 election, and also a defendant in four criminal cases, including an [ongoing hush money trial](https://www.ksl.com/article/50991570). In the Jan. 26 verdict, jurors agreed with Carroll that Trump defamed her in June 2019 by denying that he had raped her in the mid-1990s in a Bergdorf Goodman department store dressing room in Manhattan. Jurors awarded Carroll $18.3 million of compensatory damages for emotional and reputational harm, plus $65 million of punitive damages. Trump's lawyers argued that the judge instructed jurors improperly about the burden of proof needed to show malice, and erred in striking testimony about his state of mind. According to the lawyers, Trump's testimony that "I just wanted to defend myself, my family, and frankly, the presidency" was relevant to whether he had acted maliciously, and that excluding it "all but assured" a big punitive damages award. But the judge said Trump's attacks had been seen by more than 100 million people and that Trump defamed Carroll with out-of-court statements even during the trial. He also said Trump "put his hatred and disdain on full display" in the courtroom, including by muttering that the proceedings were a "witch hunt" and "con job," and walking out as Carroll's lawyer made her closing argument. "On this exceptional record, the punitive damages evidence passes constitutional muster," Judge Kaplan wrote. Last May, a [different jury](https://www.ksl.com/article/50640275/jury-finds-trump-liable-for-sexual-abuse-awards-accuser-5m) ordered Trump to pay Carroll $5 million over an October 2022 denial of Carroll's accusations, finding he had defamed and sexually abused her. Trump is also appealing that verdict. Related stories Most recent U.S. stories Related topics [Politics](https://www.ksl.com/news/politics) [U.S.](https://www.ksl.com/news/us) [Police & Courts](https://www.ksl.com/news/utah/police-and-courts)

author: @ElUniversal_SLP
title: ¡Sol, arena y mar en SLP! Ricardo Gallardo anuncia construcción de playa artificial en la Fenapo
text:
En un intento para aumentar el turismo en la capital de San Luis Potosí , el gobernador del estado Ricardo Gallardo Cardona confirmó hoy a medios de comunicación que, para el 2024 se construirá una playa artificial en las instalaciones de la Feria Nacional Potosina ( Fenapo ), la cual quedaría lista para la temporada alta de Semana Santa . “SLP será un destino turístico tan importante y reconocido como Cancún ”, afirmó el gobernador. Las instalaciones de la Fenapo se aprovecharían de tal manera que el área de los “ gritones ” (que se ha inundado en años anteriores) pueda convertirse en un contenedor “natural” del agua que simulará la playa.
“Para la arena vamos a exportar alrededor de 300 toneladas de arena de Cancún, para que esta sea blanca. Y en cuanto al agua, para que sea más realista, se le echarán cientos de kilos de sal de mar diariamente, para que la gente sienta que verdaderamente se encuentra en la playita”, afirmó el gobernador.
Visita las cascadas de la Huasteca Potosina y súbete a la tirolesa en bicicleta
¡Inocente palomita! Hoy, 28 de diciembre , se celebra el día de los Santos Inocentes , fecha en la que en diversos países como en México, se suelen realizar bromas a familiares o amigos, sin una intención verdaderamente maliciosa.
Esta tradición proviene de las fiestas saturnianas de los romanos, en las que la gente se divertía realizando diversos tipos de bromas. Sin embargo, la fecha se empalmó con la conmemoración cristiana de recordar la masacre del rey Herodes en contra de miles de niños menores de 2 años, con la intención de asesinar a Jesús.
En fin, en esta fecha, te recomendamos estar muy al pendiente y alerta, porque quien menos te lo esperes, podría estar haciéndote una broma. ¡Feliz día de los Santos Inocentes!

author: Enviroliteracy Team
title: Do jellyfish hurt dogs?
text:
Do Jellyfish Hurt Dogs? A Comprehensive Guide for Pet Owners Yes, jellyfish can hurt dogs . While a jellyfish sting is rarely fatal for our canine companions, it can cause significant pain and discomfort, leading to a range of unpleasant symptoms. Understanding the risks, recognizing the signs, and knowing how to respond is crucial for any dog owner who enjoys beach trips with their furry friend. This article will delve into everything you need to know about jellyfish stings and dogs, including what to do if your dog gets stung and how to prevent it from happening in the first place.
The Risks of Jellyfish Stings to Dogs Jellyfish are fascinating creatures, but their stinging cells, called nematocysts , are designed to inject venom into prey or potential threats. Even dead jellyfish, washed up on the shore, can still pose a danger, as the nematocysts can remain active for weeks.
When a dog comes into contact with a jellyfish, whether through sniffing, licking, biting, or simply stepping on it, the nematocysts can discharge, releasing venom into the dog’s skin. The severity of the reaction depends on several factors:
Type of Jellyfish: Different species have different venom compositions and potency. Some, like the box jellyfish , are extremely dangerous, while others cause milder reactions. Size of the Dog: Smaller dogs are generally more vulnerable to the effects of the venom. Location of the Sting: Stings on the face, particularly near the mouth or nose, can cause more significant swelling and breathing difficulties. Sensitivity of the Dog: Some dogs may be more allergic or sensitive to jellyfish venom than others. Recognizing the Signs of a Jellyfish Sting It’s essential to be able to quickly recognize the signs of a jellyfish sting in your dog. Symptoms can appear within minutes to a few hours after the incident. Common signs include:
Pain: Your dog may yelp, whine, or show signs of discomfort. Licking or Biting the Affected Area: Dogs will instinctively try to alleviate the pain by licking or biting at the sting site, which can worsen the situation. Swelling: Redness and swelling are common around the area of the sting. This can be particularly concerning if the sting is on the face or neck. Drooling: Excessive drooling can indicate nausea or discomfort. Restlessness or Agitation: Your dog may seem anxious or unable to settle down. Muscle Tremors or Cramps: In more severe cases, muscle tremors or cramps may occur. Difficulty Breathing: This is a serious symptom and requires immediate veterinary attention. Vomiting: Nausea and vomiting are also possible reactions to the venom. Fatigue: The dog might seem lethargic or unusually tired. First Aid for a Jellyfish Sting If you suspect your dog has been stung by a jellyfish, take the following steps:
Stay Calm: Your dog will sense your anxiety, so try to remain calm and reassuring. Remove Stingers: If you can see any tentacles or stingers on your dog’s skin, carefully remove them using a gloved hand or a pair of tweezers. Avoid rubbing the area, as this can cause more nematocysts to discharge. Rinse with Seawater: Rinse the affected area with seawater. Do not use fresh water , as it can trigger the release of more venom. Apply Vinegar: Vinegar is a common remedy for jellyfish stings. Soaking the area in vinegar for at least 15-30 minutes can help neutralize the venom of certain jellyfish species. Monitor Closely: Keep a close eye on your dog for any signs of a severe reaction, such as difficulty breathing or significant swelling. Seek Veterinary Care: If your dog’s symptoms are severe or do not improve after providing first aid, seek immediate veterinary care. Anaphylactic reactions, although rare, can be life-threatening. Prevention is Key The best way to protect your dog from jellyfish stings is to prevent exposure in the first place. Here are some tips:
Be Aware of Jellyfish Warnings: Pay attention to local beach warnings and advisories regarding jellyfish sightings. Keep Your Dog on a Leash: This allows you to control your dog’s movements and prevent them from wandering into areas where jellyfish may be present. Avoid Areas with Washed-Up Jellyfish: Keep your dog away from piles of seaweed or dead jellyfish on the beach. Supervise Closely: Always supervise your dog when they are near the water, especially during jellyfish season. FAQs: Jellyfish and Dogs 1. Can a jellyfish sting kill my dog? While rare, a jellyfish sting can potentially be fatal to a dog, particularly if they experience an anaphylactic reaction or are stung by a highly venomous species like a box jellyfish. However, most cases are not life-threatening, but still require prompt attention.
2. What types of jellyfish are most dangerous to dogs? The box jellyfish is considered one of the most dangerous types of jellyfish due to its potent venom. Other species, such as the Portuguese man-of-war, can also cause severe reactions.
3. How long do jellyfish stings last on dogs? The initial pain and discomfort from a jellyfish sting typically subside within a few hours to a day. However, welts and skin irritation can last for 1-2 weeks , and itchy skin rashes may appear even later.
4. Can dogs be allergic to jellyfish stings? Yes, dogs can be allergic to jellyfish stings. Allergic reactions can range from mild skin irritation to severe anaphylaxis.
5. Is it safe for my dog to swim in the ocean if there are jellyfish present? It’s generally not recommended to let your dog swim in the ocean if there are jellyfish present. The risk of a sting outweighs the enjoyment of swimming.
6. Does vinegar really work for jellyfish stings on dogs? Vinegar can be effective in neutralizing the venom of certain jellyfish species. It is recommended to soak the affected area in vinegar for at least 15-30 minutes.
7. What should I not use on a jellyfish sting? Avoid using fresh water, rubbing alcohol, ammonia, or urine on a jellyfish sting, as these can trigger the release of more venom.
8. Can a dog get stung by a jellyfish on its paw? Yes, dogs can get stung by jellyfish on their paws, especially if they step on a jellyfish that has washed ashore.
9. What do I do if my dog is having trouble breathing after a jellyfish sting? Difficulty breathing is a medical emergency. Seek immediate veterinary care.
10. Can I give my dog Benadryl after a jellyfish sting? Benadryl (diphenhydramine) can help relieve itching and swelling associated with a jellyfish sting. However, consult with your veterinarian for the correct dosage for your dog.
11. Are baby jellyfish as dangerous as adult jellyfish? Baby jellyfish, also known as larvae, can still sting and cause reactions, although their venom may be less potent than that of adult jellyfish.
12. How do I know if my dog is experiencing anaphylaxis from a jellyfish sting? Signs of anaphylaxis include difficulty breathing, hives, swelling of the face and throat, vomiting, and collapse. Seek immediate veterinary care.
13. Can petroleum jelly prevent jellyfish stings? Applying petroleum jelly to exposed skin can help prevent jellyfish stings by creating a barrier between the skin and the jellyfish tentacles.
14. Are jellyfish more prevalent at certain times of the year? Yes, jellyfish tend to be more prevalent during the warmer months, such as summer, when water temperatures are higher.
15. Where can I find more information about marine life and environmental awareness? You can find a wealth of information on marine life and environmental awareness on the The Environmental Literacy Council website. Visit enviroliteracy.org to explore resources and learn more about environmental issues.
Conclusion Enjoying the beach with your dog can be a wonderful experience, but it’s important to be aware of the potential dangers of jellyfish. By understanding the risks, recognizing the signs, and knowing how to provide first aid, you can help protect your furry friend from the pain and discomfort of a jellyfish sting. Remember, prevention is always the best approach, so stay informed about local jellyfish conditions and take precautions to keep your dog safe.

author: N.S Walia
title: AEW star leaves another wrestling title on Dynamite after being chased out of arena
text:
') > -1) { addClass($('.section-container'), 'pill-tag'); } Follow Us Share 0 Discuss 0 Discuss What's your opinion? AEW star leaves another wrestling title on Dynamite after being chased out of arena Discuss Now AEW star running after almost being attacked by another star on Dynamite (Image via AEW's X) A top AEW star came out after an intense showdown inside the squared circle on Dynamite to make a statement of her own. However, she dropped a championship belt after being chased out of the arena by her upcoming opponent.
Ad Mercedes Mone is the star mentioned above, but she was left slightly embarrassed by her next prominent match opponent, Jamie Hayter. During the April 20 edition of Dynamite, AEW Women's World Champion 'Timeless' Toni Storm was scheduled to compete in a Championship Eliminator match against Miyu Yamashita.
The match was a highly captivating showdown as the audience inside the Chartway Arena in Norfolk, Virginia were thrilled to see the encounter. As the dust settled, it was Toni Storm who emerged victorious and went 10-0 in championship eliminator matches.
Ad Trending However, right after her victory, she was confronted by Mercedes Mone. The TBS Champion proclaimed she was coming after Toni Storm and her Women's World title after beating Jamie Hayter in the Owen Cup finals at AEW Double or Nothing.
Expand Tweet Just then, Hayter made her way out to the entrance ramp. Mone tried to strike her, but she countered, which led to the CEO fleeing. But in doing so, she dropped her Undisputed British Women's title belt on the stage in an embarrassing spot. Having run Mone off, Hayter also stared down Toni Storm, signaling her intention to challenge after winning the Owen.

Nikunj is an AEW writer at Sportskeeda Wrestling. He is a BArch graduate, but his 25+ years of fandom and desire to work in this industry led him to become a pro wrestling writer. When he writes, he uses the same passion, extensive knowledge, and keeping up-to-date with the wrestling world as his USPs.
Nikunj has four years of experience. He has conducted interviews with stars like Great Khali, RVD, Mickie James, Maria Kanellis, and Heath Slater. The first match he watched was between 'Stone Cold' Steve Austin and The Rock. Interestingly, Nikunj's favorite wrestler is another historical rival of The Rock - John Cena. He has been a fan of Cena due to his Never Give Up attitude.
Besides wrestling and writing about it, Nikunj is interested in dance and basketball.
